item.title: VR studio Cloudhead Games cuts 70 percent of workforce
item.content:encoded:
Chris Kerr, Senior Editor, News, GameDeveloper.com

January 6, 2026

1 Min Read

Pistol Whip developer Cloudhead Games will make 70 percent of its workforce redundant on January 7, 2026. 

Studio CEO Denny Unger shared the news on Bluesky and said the company has been forced to reckon with "industry forces beyond our control." 

The VR studio was founded in 2013 and has worked on projects such as The Gallery, Pistol Whip, and Aperture Hand Labâ€”the latter of which was developed in collaboration with Valve. 

Unger said the company has done its best to "pad the landing" for those being laid off and has implored studios with vacancies to consider hiring them.

"The general downturn of the gaming industry, VR's still nascent challenges, including a lack of platform funding, have placed us in an impossible position. And while we've done all we can do to reinvest in our people and VR's future from prior successes, we can't build 'bigger swings' alone," wrote Unger.

"Cloudhead has weathered many storms in our 14 years in virtual reality. Our belief remains in the power of VR as a medium, as a shared dream machine the will one day transform humanity. We have no doubt VR's mainstream relevance is predestined, with future devices that do 'everything,' but it will take studios like ours to be there when the time comes."

Unger confirmed 30 percent of the Cloudhead team will remain following the cuts.
